You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I think this falls on the teacher.  Someone spoke to this above... because if you have a teacher that is just terrible and doesn't know how to manage a class of mixed ability, you get very bored \gifted\" students.  However, if the teacher knows how to differentiate properly, they can challenge your child, within the same confines of the concept being learned, at a deeper level.  Not just making your child do MORE work... but have your child do DIFFERENT work around the same topic.  Sometimes that can be as easy as asking one question to take it deeper.  _x0007__x0007_The problem I've seen with this, however, is that sometimes those \"gifted\" students still know in their head that they are getting different work.  They still think that they're smarter than the other kids, so they will tend to call the class boring.  Even though the teacher is definitely challenging the kid.  I've heard kids say, \"this class is easy\" when I KNOW I have challenged them with difficult questions on a daily basis that they struggle with.  I had a girl tell me my Honors Geometry class (as an 8th grader) was easy.  I laughed... I said, \"This class isn't EASY!  You just got an A on a High School Geometry Honors Mid-Term.  That's hard to do!  It's not easy... I watch you work HARD every day!  I see you thinking... I see you struggle... I watch you debate... This is work!   And you work hard!  Just because you got an A, doesn't mean it's easy."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I think that it is a great way to see that students look at things differently.  In the video, it seemed like no two people saw the dot card in the same way.  It's a very open-ended strategy that reduces the pressure of students getting the wrong answer, as well as helps them see that numbers can be broken up in different ways.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: <nameRedac_<anon_screen_name_redacted>>_x0007_You are so right.  I had a second niece last year in class----she hated math because she believed she was supposed to know the math coming in.  We worked on self-confidence and competing only for herself and against herself.  We talked about learning one new thing a day.  We talked about celebrating small victories.  I received a letter this year from her----she isn't having trouble in math; she said she wanted to thank me for believing in her and helping her believe in herself------she had learned that it wasn't all about the math, but what she brought to math and what she was willing put into math.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Kids get negative messages about math from family and friends.  My mom told me that she couldn't do math, so that was probably why it was hard for me.  My dad, on the other hand, was great at math.  However, when I would ask him a question, he would try to explain it to me the way he worked through problems which was using a slide-rule.  I had never seen a slide-rule before, so was additionally stressed because I could not understand the tool he used!  Most of my friends had difficulty with math, so we would complain to each other about how awful it was.

Right in the middle of the front of my room I have the statement \If at first you don't succeed, try, try again.' I want to go into my classroom right now and change that to: The more you try, the more you grow your brain! It makes so much sense! Encourage the kids to grow their brains! Back to what Michelle Obama said, \"...it's hard work!...\"  \"Keep working at it, do you feel your brain?\"  I know the kids are feeling their brain working, we just need to focus on the positive of hard work. It's ok to feel your brain working and growing - it can be what we call \"frustration,\" that's when you know your brain is growing!"

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: This year, you may have a different experience than you have had in math class previously.  I am interested in your thinking and your learning.  I WILL give you problems that do not have just one way to be solved.  They WILL be difficult at times.  I expect you to put forth effort to try them, but I do NOT expect that you will get the right answer or even an answer at times.  The class will be about learning what we can from these difficult problems and our mistakes in order to make progress in our learning. I will not tell you a procedure for these problems.  Instead, I will be here to encourage you, ask you lots and lots of questions and learn along with you. None of us knows it all, and none of us will be the end of the year together.  I expect to learn about your thinking and hopefully some math as well. You should expect to learn about math but also about your own thinking. If you are putting forth effort and making progress, that is what will be valued instead of the number of questions right and wrong!

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Although I have great deal of sympathy with the idea of mixed ability teaching, I do feel that before any such system can be introduced, the onerous formal planning, assessment, record-keeping and administrative burdens that most teachers in the UK labour under needs to be reduced first. You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I have to say that I think for already-scarred students, it's going to take a whole lot more than lip service to convince them that mistakes are good. They've got lots of math and attitude stuff to unlearn. I don't think the research that says it takes longer to \unlearn\" than to learn -- as in more practice, and more successes -- has been tossed, so I'm simply going to call that idea that we need students making mistakes all the time wrong.   It might work peachily for students accustomed to being right in other stuff... it definitely works for *me.*   I've had to learn from experience, though, that my students do much, much better if they get to practice the stuff they know enough to get past the working-memory-killing anxious part; when they have relaxed, then they can start making the connections."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Hello everyone.  I am <nameRedac_<anon_screen_name_redacted>>, and I am a Computer Mathematics teacher at a middle school from West Virginia.  I have 25 years of mathematics teaching experience at the junior high/middle school levels.  My present position consisted of students completing mathematics lessons on the computer using the PLATO learning platform.  Then the county switched to APANGEA.  Last year the APANGEA learning platform changed its name to Think Through Math.  When students return to school in August, they will be using MATHIA from Carnegie.  _x0007__x0007_I really look forward to this class, as I hope to gain some new ideas and learn from the recent research on strategies and techniques on how to get students to learn math.  This is extremely important because I teach in a low socio-economical school and whose student population is not real excited about mathematical learning.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: One thing the number cards do that I didn't see mentioned in the first few posts below is that they visually reinforce the idea that numbers can be broken up in many different ways. The discussion of the different ways people viewed the dots opens avenues for others to begin to consider how many different decompositions there are, and that these decompositions lead to many different arithmetic computations. Finally, the visual aspect of the exercise leaves a lasting impression almost like a puzzle that people might carry in the back of their minds as a reminder to think about numbers in different and use the relationships of the sub-parts to understand the numbers more deeply.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I work with students on a one to one basis, so I don't necessarily \group\" my students in any group in particular. But all that said, I see the results of students feeling like they're dumb and stupid when it comes to math. I don't know where they've heard these messages, but I do hope that message in their head changes. I've noticed that if I expect more from students, if they are available, then they will rise to the occasion and work hard. I also find that if I expect too much, they won't even begin the class and refuse to do anything. _x0007__x0007_After viewing these videos I'm now curious about what it'd look like if we did group work, instead of one-to-one teaching. I think it'd be interesting to see my students working together with other students opposed to working things out with me. So maybe my school needs more groups, opposed to eliminated them!"

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: For those with moderate disabilities, I think they can/will have growth and I think they can access math learning.  However, they may not access it the same way. So while they may be able to understand concepts, they may have difficulties with processes.  Or they may have working memory issues.  If their \disability\" can be broken down and specifically identified, then appropriate accommodations/modifications can allow them to access math both from a problem solving point of view and from an aesthetic point of view.  However, if we continue to evaluate them based on whether they can do long division using the \"standard\" algorithm (or some other process), then we will never give them the opportunity to meet math."

(Especially when we are talking about high school curricula and heavy concepts to deliver, you just feel like you need to invest every second to explain as much as possible to explain a brand new concept / idea)

They will use Technology and present their product to the class Using PowerPoint.  They will be practical by writing problems that connects to everyday life, and creative in their presentations demonstrating skills of the 21st Century skills.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I think you made a wise choice, taking into account the dynamics of the classroom actually.  We know as teachers, that every set of kids we get each year requires us to adapt and modify our teaching to what is most conducive to the learning environment.  Having taught kindergarten, challenging the high group was ALWAYS my biggest challenge because the range of where students are at in their learning process is so very wide in kindergarten.

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I think it helps people see that even the simplest things, like counting have multiple approaches, that are like and unalike in interesting ways.  It helps get away from the idea that math is about one right answer (in this case 10), and moves toward the idea that math is about multiple approaches.  It can help people feel like their contributions are interesting and important.  It could also be a good setting to develop good group discussion norms.  You also get to see how numbers are made up of other numbers, which leads into interesting things later.  (E.g. you can't do 15*12 = 15*10 + 15*2 without knowing that 12 can be broken into 10 and 2.  In this video an interesting thing we saw is that 10 = 4+3+2+1, which is part of a very interesting series (triangle numbers)).

Now, it is back to tracking since it has been deemed important that 8th graders are able to take geometry if they want! Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: It is scary because of the effect it has on students. I teach pre-GED level in a community college setting in the CUNY system. Many of my students in my classes are products of a failed public school system. Thus many of my students walk into my classroom the first day with a huge dark shadow of failure dogging their every effort. I am new to teaching, about two years now. It is a second career for me; I was, in another life, an education program coordinator. So I have much to learn about teaching._x0007_And although my heart is in the right place it has been a struggle for me to try to help my students overcome this heavy belief that they are failures, especially when it comes to math. _x0007_Recently I was talking to a new colleague who just joined our staff this year, but who has been teaching for awhile. She was talking about the difficulty of teaching to so many different levels of ability in our classrooms. And she is right. We do have students with such a variety of strengths and ability who come from so many different backgrounds. So it is a dilemma how to catch the attention and interest of all. But I was horrified to hear her say that she grouped her students, that she felt it was the best way to teach to all skill levels. While I know that I lose many students (we all do in these programs) for whatever reasons and few finish out the semester, I do know that by the end of the semester I can look around my classroom and see all students working together. Yes my lesson planning and teaching are always a work in progress and I have so much room for improvement, but I almost cry to think of the adults in her classes who are assigned to their group and subtly told, this is it for you, I am confirming your negative sense of your abilities. This and no higher. But until this course and the information on the brain research and mind-set for growth, formative teaching, I had no words to counter her oh so reasonable pronouncements. Now I have the language and the tools.

She helped me to believe in myself as a critical reader of fiction and nonfiction texts. On the other hand, a single message can also have a very negative impact. This year I am beginning to use a flipped classroom approach, which will allow students to adjust their pace as they go through the material. At the outset of each unit, I will give them a list of the learning goals for that unit and the resources and problem sets that are meant to help them reach each goal. My new growth-mindset task has to do with self-evaluation. I will use Google Docs to make a form related to each learning goal. When a student finishes the tasks for a given goal, they will have to fill out the Google form, which will ask them to evaluate their own understanding of the goal (scale of 1 to 5), give a reason for their choice, and write what they plan to do next. There will also be an optional \Something that would help me more is...\" which they can fill in if they choose.

_x0007_

This is a growth-mindset task because it will focus students on what the goals are and on their own perception of where they are relative to those goals. It is also a management tool for me because I can use the Google spreadsheets to help me keep track of who is where in the curriculum, which will help me in my planning for how to use class time.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Have you tried using any specific study team strategies? For instance, I have seen teacher get great results using team roles, as artificial as they are. One idea is to give each student within a team a name tag that on one side, says their role. Task Manager, Recorder/reporter, Resource Manager, Facilitator. Then on the other side, you list sample questions the student in that role might ask. And you enforce it! You have a participation quiz where you tell the students \Today I'm going to be assessing how well you work as a team, and in particular, I will be looking at how well you perform in your role.\" This sets the expectation that you want students to ALL be involved, not just some of them. Here's a link that explains some of this: http://www.cpm.org/pdfs/studyTeam/Using_Team_Roles_with_Study_Teams.pdf _x0007__x0007_Hope that helps somewhat!"

I struggle with the idea that leveling is bad.  Within each class I have huge ranges of abilities.  My classes are hardly homogeneous groupings.  For example this past year in Pre-Algebra (not leveled classes) I had students who didn't know their basic math facts and couldn't solve the most basic equations without assistance and students who could complete each task assigned with proficiency.  In Pre-Algebra I was working under the (soon to be dismissed) California State Standards.  My Math 6 classes were not leveled.  I was working under the Common Core State Standards for these classes.  I was able (for the most part) to provide challenging activities so that the high, at grade level, and low students were all able to solve and make progress towards mastering the standards.  I often saw the high students become the students of the low students.  The low students often had a better understanding of the process (and got hung up on the arithmetic) than the high students who had memorized the algorithm (process) for solving that type of problem. _x0007__x0007_That is what I love about education. Every class and every year is different.  It is our job as educators to present the material so it is challenging to the majority of the students.  I saw something in one of the blogs we have looked at - it said that you have to be ok with not being everything to every student. After they finished, I asked which thinking strength might bring the most success.  I used this opportunity to share the following ideas with my classes. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I have a high proportion of perfectionist students in my class, so I have developed several ongoing procedures to model learning from mistakes, and to put mistakes in learning perspective. When I call on students attempting to answer a challenging question (and sometimes I cold call), I will sometimes make explicit that I am checking for understanding, or trying to evaluate where students are now in their thinking. Because it works for me, I also rhetorically ask \will the floor open and swallow him if he's wrong?\" or \"will anyone die if she makes a mistake?\" In addition, especially during math, I remind them to be watching carefully because I make frequent mistakes, or get confused. Often, if someone catches a mistake I'm making, I give them a point,and invite them up to show us their thinking. Occasionally, I'm not wrong, but the student works through a confusion (which others usually share). Similarly, students routinely come up to demonstrate how they got answers. Time permitting, we have people show all the different ways they arrived at the answer. Those who get different answers come up, partly so we can resolve the issue, figure out how and why different answers arose -- which one is \"right,\" and what error in thinking or calculation caused the mistake. Sometimes students can identify where another student has a confusion before I can, and explain it better, since they have already \"been there,\" and worked through the error."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: It's always been a frustration of mine when students focus solely on getting the \right answer\" and don't realize that being able to explain their thinking or strategy is the key. Students would wait for me to walk them through the steps or copy the answer from a neighbor just to get the answer on the page. I got tired of watching students wait for others around them to do their thinking for them. Recently, I've rearranged my desk groupings and utilized a cooperative group structure where each member of the group is responsible for contributing and being able to explain the thinking involved in solving a problem. As struggles arise, I am available for coaching and they also coach each other. As we share out our answers and strategies, they never know which member of the group will be the \"reporter\" so they all have to be prepared. This has really helped break that didactic contract. I see students really taking more responsibility for their own learning and moving beyond the whole idea of just getting the right answer."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Teaching students the way they will be tested is a research-based principle. Kudos to you! Study guides with procedures? Not everything has to be a problem-based learning. Indeed, much research suggests that problem-based learning works better if a student has background knowledge. Notice, no where did I say that the problem-based learning needs to be exactly like the procedures already taught. By giving students a path, they can be prepared to think deeper and in a different way. Also, repeated attempts at the same procedures in novel concepts increases memorization and understanding. _x0007__x0007_There should be a mix! So many want to act like worksheets are fake and problem-based learning is authentic. Learning comes in all different styles and methods; for example, Japan does a great deal of memorization before problem-based learning. Other countries, like Germany, do very little problem-based learning. Yet, both countries are at the top of the world's math tests. The point is that like solving a math problem, there are several paths to teaching.

I started off struggling with math in high school.  It was very difficult for me and I had to work hard at it which looking back I attribute my more eventual learning of the subject (if that can be said).  But some time in college, I seemed to have a better grasp of the subject.  I feel like to be successful in math(or any subject) is that you have to have an inquiry for it (which we are all born with), it must be presented in a way that is somewhat accesible and there has to be some perseverance and \risk taking\" on the part of the student.  In my classroom, I try to stoke the inquiry by presenting problems that are accessible and somewhat open ended. But getting student's to take a risk, try the problem for an hour or day can be tough because they have been conditioned to think that solving a math problem is something on the magnitude of minutes rather than hours or even days.  So it comes as no surprise that completion level of college math is low.  By the time they get to those classes, the inquiry and fun has been driven out of them in favor of a quick solution that you either get or don't and this idea of toughness/perseverance is non-existant.  My goal as a math teacher is to try to build this back up and encourage the risk taking."

Do these students that barely pass a class have the appropriate understanding in order to process more advanced material?  So in a way it is the teaching methods of the courses. By the time they reach college and have to take remedial courses, they will have been discouraged to continue, because why even try if you can't even pass a remedial course in college?

In the MYP (Middle Years Program) there is the Extended class with the idea that these students will be taking HL (higher level) for their final two years in the DP (Diploma) program. _x0007__x0007_I have told students that aren't in the extended that they can still aim for the HL course if that's their goal. It's difficult though and you can see it on their faces when they've worked so hard. The problem with the extended classes for these bright, wonderful thinkers is how fast they crack through the content. I've had wonderful middle schoolers unravel in HS maths because there was no time to breathe let alone think or try to solve something a different way. I saw them again two years later and had to restore their mathematical belief in themselves. These extended classes (depending on the school I suppose) support rapidity. It's a big problem in Grade 10 when the teachers have to submit, by March assessments using all of the criteria and this must include a test. _x0007__x0007_I will be teaching in a small school so no grouping is possible. We will all be doing the same tasks but hopefully open and differentiated. _x0007__x0007_At a school in Sydney, 1999 (not an IB school) I was given the \bottom class\" at a girls school in the outer western suburbs. They did not have a positive feeling about mathematics or themselves as learners or being smart. We had some discussions about what had been covered, progress, was there anything they had enjoyed that year (I came in half way through) and if not what about any year before that?_x0007__x0007_Their test scores were very low and everyone sat the same final exam (in grade 8!). _x0007_They seemed to agree that shapes and geometry were okay so I suggested we look at it in depth and ignore the rest unless we found the time. I told them we would all learn something really well rather than trying to get through all of it. They agreed. _x0007_Of course there is numeracy and algebra in geometry, but I didn't call it that, they were just tools to solve problems. Out of seven classes, our class came fourth (averages). You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: One thing that has worked in my elementary school is the introduction of daily word problems.  Our administration believes that using math story problems in our classrooms can give every student a chance to develop understanding of basic math concepts.  This has been highly successful.  First, we introduce a real life situation based on our math objective.  We then have the students tell each other the story and what the specific task is.  We then have the students use unifix cubes, drawings, numerical representations of how they solve the problem, using at least one representation that can be put down on paper.  This lets all level of achievers to use whatever forum they want. When higher students finish, we give them the task to solve it another way and show their thinking. As students work individually, the teacher goes around and asks students what they are showing (how they are making sense of their thinking) and selects three students to present their strategies to the class.  These presentations are to be from simple to more complex so that all students can see/relate their thinking to another way of solving the problem.  This has been highly successful in our school practices and has shown us that all students can do math.  I found that at the end of doing this for an entire year, most if not all students were able to express their math thinking with ease and were more than eager to share and be presenters to the class.  I noticed doing daily math word problems also obliterated the anxiety that often accompanies such problems.  Last year, one of my students exclaimed, \I'm not afraid of story problems anymore.\"  This was all the proof I needed.  I'm continuing this practice!"

If you get a math problem right, there's not a whole lot going on in your brain because you probably already knew how to do it.  If all the work I give you is easy, then I'm cheating you out of new learning.  If you get a math problem wrong, it's time to try out other ideas and persist with figuring it out.  Doing this is really cool because it will actually cause your brain to form new connections -- this is REAL LEARNING.  Your brain is actually growing and getting stronger every time you make a mistake and return to it to experiment with new and different ideas.  We're going to have so much fun trying out a lot of different ideas to figure out really cool and challenging math questions, just like scientists, doctors and computer experts do in their jobs every day.  I believe in every one of you and I know that you are going to learn and grow this year!

There is more chance of effective, critical and fresh feedback ideas._x0007__x0007__x0007_I also use the independent and joint solution strategy. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I work with the GED students in the Bridge to Healthcare class where I teach reading, writing, and math. Our students are put in class based on their reading scores, not math. As the result, I have students whose math skills vary from 4-5 grade to really advanced (I had a student with B.A. in engineering from the other country). I find it challenging to work with students with so different skills and constantly looking for new ways of engaging everyone and giving them opportunities to learn regardless of their math levels. I believe that my students are better off by being in the same group. However, sometimes it can be very difficult to keep everyone developing and engaged. What I found works great is when students work in small groups on problems that require them to figure out answers (there is no one best way to do a problem). Also, I develop a set of questions for students who might be \stuck\" and for students who are done with the assignment and need a challenge. I found that students really like to create their own similar problems and ask their classmates to solve those. My lower level students show incredible improvements over the course of the semester, although sometimes they need more than 14 weeks to get to the GED math level. The students who need to do another semester are more willing to come back to school again as they grow to understand that developing math skill takes time. Also,I want to believe that they develop/start developing the growth mindset and as the result are willing to keep trying to reach their goal of passing the GED test."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I teach 4-5 grade students in a resource setting. Most of my students have learning disabilities. By nature we group our students by levels and teach each student on their instruction level. Last year I had a group of 6th graders I was working with which I was giving very remedial work to. They were able to do this work and were successful. But when they went back to their regular education classroom they were very lost in math and wanted to know how to do that math. So, a few months into school I decided to just \re-teach\" what they were learning in their other classroom. I showed them how to use tools like calculators to solve problems and showed them how to organize their thinking while doing math. They were SO successful. They LOVED the harder work, and even though it took them a lot longer to solve the problems than with the remedial work, they loved it and loved being challenged. If we assume that they can't do math you aren't giving them the chance to grow and learn. I have completely changed the way I teach math since this experience and teach all of my students on Grade level in Math."

They have not moved past sets for counting, do not know multiplication tables, subtract by counting on their fingers, and show other signs of minimal effort applied to work from earlier grades.  They often do not know place values, and they almost always have no home support or divided support between split households._x0007__x0007_The remainder of the 31 kids are well past that.  Our district does not believe in retention after second grade, so if the first grade teacher does not retain and reteach then the student is passed on to the next grade.  Since California did away with the 20 to 1 classroom size, all grades (K-5) have 30 or 31 kids. The ones who arrive unprepared in Kinder often lag behind.  A few catch up by third, but it is pretty common for the kid to be three or four grade levels behind in math by fifth grade for this group.  The district does not supply aides.  We just received funding for a math program for remediation (DreamBox Math) two years ago, and I heard from third grade teachers that that helped._x0007__x0007_I am not saying to retain kids. I have been a special education teacher for much of the past few years and the schools in which I have worked continue to have ability grouping (even though it may not be called that all of the time). I have been guilty of taking my small group of students, and giving them work that is not challenging enough and does not encourage higher level thinking or a growth mindset.  I have not seen, read or heard about what is really looks like to have a heterogeneous grouping that works at addressing the needs of all students. What I would love to see, is for the students I work with to remain in their regular classrooms for the entire math lesson, and then break up into smaller groups and work on the exact same concept, but have the work be differentiated and possibly the modality of response shifted so that all students can learn and be challenged. You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: First of all, people can become aware of how their own mind works, when confronted with a task involving numbers, calculations, or concepts - and even better, they can realize that other people's minds may or may not work the same as their own.  Additionally, I would assume once students see other students' ideas, they might begin to see relationships between numbers and ideas that they might not have seen before and also see that everyone's ideas are considered important and not better than anyone else's - perhaps allowing students to think of themselves and others as being capable in math.  The different methods that are discussed can also help students have a better sense of operations, properties, algorithms, and algebraic thinking as they begin to see another layer of math thinking that isn't about the answer or a calculation.  These talks also engage everyone somewhat equally because there isn't one person who raises their hand and gets the answer correct.  It would seem it could hold the attention better if all of the students know they might be asked to share and it would be potentially more engaging to have many people active and discussing, raising the interest level.  Seeing different ways of doing math problems would seem to help students become more flexible in number thinking and better at decomposing math problems and so increase the ability to understand relationships within our number system - the key to further math success.

They probably did problems that were multi-step, multi-concept and had little scaffolding. _x0007__x0007_If you want to make small steps in a traditional classroom, here are a few suggestions:_x0007__x0007_1.  Ask the question first. It can be a question you already have, and it does not have to be a great open ended question. Do this right from the beginning of the year so it sets the \tone.\"  You will get complaints at first that you are not \"teaching\" but the students adjust. Find a problem that has more than one way to do it. Don't show them what to do, just let them work and ask questions.  Hopefully you will get more than one solution to discuss with the class. For example- Give the students 3 ordered pairs and ask if they are all on the same line.  It can be done by graphing, comparing slopes, writing the equation a line through 2 points and showing the third point is on it, or using distances.  If a student finds one method quickly, challenge him to find another. _x0007__x0007_2.  Don't label or tell the students the \"topic\" of a problem before you do the problem.  This takes away the necessity of thinking about what skill to use.  AFTER you have finished the problem ask the students how they think the problem should be labeled.  What was the key idea?  What skills did they need?_x0007__x0007_3.  Take the scaffolding out of the problem and let the students figure out what they need to do. Let them decide on their own process.  Sometimes you will be surprised; they find methods better than yours. Have the students work in groups and you can walk around to answer questions and give hints if necessary.  When the class is done, the students can generalize the thought process or procedure for the solution._x0007__x0007_4.  If you review, don't go in any order or have labels on the problems.  Mix everything together so the students have to think and figure out what concepts apply._x0007__x0007_5.  When I test, I always make sure there are a couple of problems that require concepts from previous units. If there is concept from an earlier unit that caused difficulty, revisit it during class and include it on the next test.  If a student thinks he is never going to be asked about a topic again, he will not remediate.  There needs to be incentive to corre"

If all of those   The best way to learn math is to share ideas (e.g. convince myself, convince a friend, convince an enemy) If the students in a group all have the same low ability, there is no one there to speak the language of math.  Oftentimes in a mixed group, those who are 'low' actually see the concepts of the math the best.  Often our high achievers are only 'high' because they have been taught methods and procedures and have memorized their math facts.  They are not necessarily better mathematicians. My biggest educational 'wish' is that all students would have the opportunities afforded to the upper class.  How can schools/society make that happen? In my opinion, the swimming analogy does not match up well with learning mathematics.

I try to give as many students a chance to use the SB to solve problems and share ideas.  Once the work has been assigned, I will give those who \switch off\" one-on-one help, and assign them maybe only a few questions to focus on . The quick-finishers can play one of the many math games I have available, or take an extra practice sheet that I have available.  Whatever they do, it has to be math related.  Sometimes, if I check their work I find that they really haven't gotten it yet, and I'll send them back for corrections. If they really have aced it, then I will ask if they'd like to peer-tutor other students. It's a much more friendly, collaborative, inclusive environment."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Once students get put in a lower track, as a teacher, I see more behavior problems. They believe that they can't do the math. They struggle, or don't even know how to start. They feel dumb and think that anything would be better that staying in this class, and letting their peers see them struggle and be stupid. Acting out can get them attention, even if it is negative. They can get out of class, if they are too disruptive. If they get to leave, their peers won't see how hard this math really is. The problem is that once they get used to acting out, it is very hard to go back to a system of no tracking. All it takes is a couple of students who are disruptive, and the entire class suffers. We went to no tracking for one year, and the teachers didn't like it due to disruptive students. Should Special Education students be put in a regular class? These students are easily intimidated, and don't feel comfortable letting other students know how much they struggle. What if they can't keep up with the rest of the class. What about students who are a year or more advanced? Many of them have had more opportunities, sometimes put in Hi-Cap, (High Capabilities), classes. Would everyone excel if they were given the same opportunities? What about kids who don't want to put out very much effort? It seems that some students are just lazy or unmotivated. What about students who are absent a lot? At our school, we can have students who are absent 20, 30, 40, 50, 60 or more days. What about students who get put in Juvenile Hall, and are not there for instruction? What about students who are suspended and are not there for 45 days, because they get in trouble for drugs or alcohol? In our school district, students are passed on each year, regardless of their grades. The rules change when they get to high school. All of a sudden class are for credit with only a D and above given as a passing grade. Is a D student really going to do well in the second year of math, when they have not demonstrated that they know the material from the first year? I do not feel that these studies have addressed these issues.

They are not all on the same trajectory when they learn, and they may be able to advance quickly in some areas but not in others.  I teach kindergarten, and I pull students to work with me on various tasks in small groups, but the groups are formed based on a particular skill or learning concept and the group members need.  They are not pegged into one group for the whole year.  My groups change as often as the skill or concept has been learned.  Some students exit the group quickly and sometimes others move in.  Many times what many would consider a traditionally high student will be with a traditionally low student because they both need practice with a particular skill or concept.  I don't need to slow down a whole group of students because one needs a lesson, nor do I stop a student from learning something new simply because the others in the group are not ready.  Being flexible with the students in a classroom is key to helping them get the right lessons at the right time.

The lessons designed by teachers who have higher track students are often much different than the ones created by teachers who have lower track students. Colleagues who teach lower track classes often say material is too difficult for their students.  They want to skip topics, give students \cheat sheets\" or scaffold every problem.  They have a title or target goal on problems but this eliminates the student's need to decide what skills to use.  Part of doing mathematics is sorting and applying skills when appropriate. They don't give their students a chance to struggle and grow, because they don't believe in their students. You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: We do not use ability grouping for math in my school.  Two years ago, in 3rd grade (which is the grade I teach) our administrator asked the 3rd grade team to split our students by ability for reading.  We did this for several reasons, but primarily because we had to document for RTI (Response to Intervention) for those students reading below grade level.  We used several tools to determine where to place children and the children were never told that they were being \grouped\", just that we were changing teachers for reading groups. [And, yes, some of them could figure out what we were doing.]  The groups were fluid, however, so that if a child made significant progress in reading ability, he or she was \"moved\" to another teacher (essentially another/higher group).  What we discovered was that those children who were so very low that they couldn't read was that once they were placed in a very small class, they began to participate more AND their reading difficulties became more obvious.  Why? Because suddenly those children could not disappear into the larger group.  They felt more at ease responding because they were in the same boat as everyone else at the reading table.  Most of those children made huge strides in their reading levels._x0007__x0007_As a teacher I noticed that even though we used several tools, some children were incorrectly placed.  The students in my class were reading way beyond the 3rd grade level and were considered the advanced group; however, some of those students simply did not have the maturity to be in such a class and found themselves way over their heads._x0007__x0007_I know this is not about math and I recognize the problems with grouping or labeling; however, I see the benefits for those 3rd graders who are so woefully behind in their reading skills.  They need that small group setting--those intervention strategies to bring them up to speed."

When we made mistakes, it was not pleasant - we frequently heard \"why can't you do this, why did you get it wrong, you're not stupid, you must not have studied hard enough or practiced long enough!\" My sister (who skipped 2 grades) would be in tears but I was a much more stubborn kid who didn't cry, already knew I wasn't stupid, and was lucky in memorizing procedures (I skipped 1 grade). Sis developed ELA skills to become a writer, lawyer and executive; I became a teacher with a doctorate in math ed. I recently found out how profoundly negative and sustaining my sister's math learning experiences had been - despite her use of math to manage multimillion dollar corporate accounts in her career and personal portfolio accounts, she says \"I'm not good at math!\" And when I'm feeling just a little mean, I know I can bring sis to tears if I invoke her memories of 11th grade math class drills. Needless to say I now know so much more about math, affect, and math learning and teaching - I imagine my dad and I would have very interesting conversations. Your second equation doesn't get you any closer to that goal, nor the third.  In such a problem I tell students that we are trying to find out what x is, not what 4x is, or x + 2, but just x.  To do that we need some kind of an answer such as \x = .....\".  To get there we need to get x all by itself by using manipulations that maintain the sanctity of the equals sign.  This is where the creativity comes in -- the student can do whatever they want.  Some manipulations will get closer to the goal of \"x - ....\", some won't.  It doesn't matter how fast they get there.  Doing manipulations that don't help helps the student see what will and what won't help.  You could view this as making a mistake if the goal is to get to \"x = ...\" as quickly as possible.  This is where the learning comes in.  From your first equation, if the student was stuck, I'd point out there are an awful lot of x's there, is there a way to put them together."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: When students are taught procedures before they are given a chance to explore a concept, they are, by necessity, limited in their ability to think mathematically. The procedure becomes tied to the context under which it was taught and students will struggle to see how the procedure can be applied in a different context. The simplicity of the question provides every student with an entry point to the question. Then, as students describe their way of looking at the question, the rest of the students continue to look at the problem through different lenses. Everyone, then, sees that mathematical concepts are flexible and malleable rather than rigid. This also provides a platform from which to launch deeper mathematical concepts (in this case, some examples are symmetry; associativity, commutativity and distributivity; patterning)

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: There is so much tension between our lords and masters (in the UK this is Ofsted) and what we, as maths teachers, truly want to achieve. Our 'auditors' are only interested in the measurable. I believe this comes about because the amount of progress that is genuinely measurable in a 30 minute observation session is so small that these people cannot determine whether real learning is actually taking place. They know nothing about individual students, where they started at the beginning of the lesson or where they could or should be at the end of the lesson. Consequently they invent a series of parameters which they find easy to measure and comment upon but which often have little or no importance in the learning of mathematics. So we teachers bend over backwards trying to satisfy a bunch of criteria that keeps our departments and schools out of the \Requires Improvement\" category but which, in fact, contribute to the very problem this course is trying to address. And here's what I really fear, no matter how much we write about this here, in this course, and indeed elsewhere, Mr. Gove will take absolutely no notice of any of it whatsoever!"

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Hi Margherite,_x0007__x0007_From a maths tutors point of view (and student teacher), all I can suggest is to ask students more questions which require them to explain their steps and how and why the standard algorithm works. And to really push this philosophy in your classroom. _x0007__x0007_As a tutor, I get frustrated because so many students come to me saying that their teacher forces them to squash all of their maths onto one line on the page, or to rule a line down the page and squash as many questions onto one page, meaning they have no room to actually explain their steps (which is what I ask them to do, and their teachers never seem to ask them to do). The students I see are never asked conceptual problems, only the basic \solve this, and this and this\". _x0007__x0007_If they are asked to explain their steps and asked to explain in their own words how something works, if you ask questions like these, it won't matter what the teaching philosophy of the tutor is, the students will still have to get used to explaining what they are doing and how it works. Yes some tutors and parents may just give the student the answer, but the student will likely learn more from answering (or having answered) questions about how and why something works than they would from the old \"solve for x over and over and over again\" routine (of course this still has its place, they need practice actually using and doing maths). _x0007__x0007_It is easy to blame the parents and tutors, but if you don't ask the conceptual questions, then parents and tutors are going to simply show the child how to apply a rule._x0007__x0007_Cheers, <nameRedac_<anon_screen_name_redacted>>"

With A/B partners I have the As explain something to the Bs, or the B's, to the As, and then often times the table group will then discuss as a group comparing their solutions and discussing things.  I've found that by having flexible groups, students don't feel like they are being pigeon holed into a particular group.  I've also found that sometimes students surprise me because they may work really well with a particular partner and they both really bring out the best thinking in one another.  Also, it allows students to work with different types of personalities, which is also a good life skill.  Therefore, I think grouping should be flexible and change often.

So, now they would see 30 x 25 and think of quarters in their hands and get right to 750 instead of having to break things down. _x0007_She is also doing more than describing things as correct; she's explaining things in context of those disgustingly important math principles like the distributive property (as opposed to giving out a worksheet with equations where we get to match them up, then abandoning that for the rest of the year, then sticking it on the 'final' for them to get wrong)._x0007_      She also looks for the language precision -- clarifying that no, he wasn't multiplying by zero; he was multiplying by multiples of ten.  _x0007_    I notice that plain ol' rules do have their place when they refer to the \"Rule of ten\" instead of describing a compressed mental process. _x0007_    Then she's diagramming things, spatially (as opposed to drawing 25 \"things\"), so that those properties are more visible... showing that distributive property in assorted ways."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I am on the fence re the argument against grouping/laning, whatever you want to call it._x0007__x0007_As an example, one year at our elementary school, our 3rd graders were chosen to pilot a district math program.  The entire 3rd Grade class (80 students or so) was  grouped by ability into 4 groups.  The teachers were skeptical.  However, by the end of the year, they were surprised to see that many students in the lower groups benefited by having more opportunities to be the \coaches\" and \"helpers\" in their groups.  It actually left many students feeling more empowered and confident about their math abilities._x0007__x0007_Now, what about other areas, say for example, sports. When we have different teams such as AYSO vs. Club, Varsity vs. JV, minor league vs. major league, A team vs. B team, etc.  is this not grouping by ability?  Is this bad for the athletes?  Do we go around saying, \"Hey, stop the grouping!\"?_x0007__x0007_I bring up these examples as a way of asking is it grouping that is harmful or is it something else?  _x0007__x0007_I personally think it has more to do with our mindset about math ability vs. almost any other kind of ability. For example, do we say you're either good at reading or you're not? But for whatever reason, a lot of people believe that math is one of those subjects you're either good at or not, implying you can't get better at it._x0007__x0007_That's what we need to work on.  We need to let students know that with hard work and perseverance they can be successful at math.  Isn't that what we tell our kids when they are trying to master hitting the baseball or shooting a 3-pointer?  Now whether our kids will ever play professionally, that's another story, just as in not every student may go on to major in math.  But didn't they have the opportunity to enjoy and appreciate baseball or basketball (or math)?_x0007__x0007_Many of the strategies that Jo has outlined in this course support the quest to make math meaningful, accessible, fun, open, creative, collaborative.  (Funny, many of our other school subjects are taught this way.)  I think changing our mindset that math abilities are fixed and adopting new ways to teach math including more open-ended problems, peer sharing, collaboration, feedback will move us in the right direction."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: It's easier to grasp if you begin with simple numbers. For example, If I start with a piece of wood that is 12 inches long, how many 2-inch pieces can I get out of it? Answer: 6 pieces of wood, each 2-inches long. That's the same as 1 divided by 1/6.    If I start with a piece of wood that is 12 inches long, how many 3-inch pieces can I get? Answer: 4 pieces. That's 1 divided by 1/4.    If I start with a piece of wood that is 12 inches long, how many 6-inch pieces can I get? Answer: 2 pieces. That's 1 divided by 1/2.  So far, all these lengths (2,3,6) are factors of 12, so we get whole number answers. The number of pieces we get goes down as the length of the piece desired increases.   If I start with a piece of wood that is 12 inches long, how many 8-inch pieces can I get? Answer: 1 piece that is 8-inches plus one piece leftover that is 4 inches (half the desired length), or 1.5 8-inch pieces.  That's 1 divided by 2/3.

Their achievement in mathematics spirals downward at that point and stretches to the future.  It makes me think that geometry is really poorly taught in high schools.  It should be more visual and less abstract than pure numbers, but I know many students feel that they are unable to do proofs.  I don't think presenting geometry in real world problems is the only strategy; however, that could be involved one per week or once per unit.  I think that students have to work more slowly with the concepts, using concrete objects, technology simulations, etc. until they have an intuition about it.  I hypothesize that males have a slight advantage in geometry because in our culture they are more apt to work with models, moving toys, tools, and even sports, which have geometric underpinnings.  Perhaps providing connections of geometry to art, photography, room and house design would broaden the real world examples.  And adopt a master learning sequence; if students don't get it, they get lots of opportunities to learn.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Not an easy solution, but one possible approach is to have students working in mixed ability groups within the classroom.  Then, with enough structure and practice, students learn that full discussions within their groups where they are helping each other must come before asking a teacher for help.  Although sometimes there still are a few students who continue to struggle or disengage and it becomes frustrating to the highest achievers, usually the strong students find that explaining and teaching helps them to solidify and better understand their own learning.  _x0007__x0007_In addition, having challenge problems or extensions for almost every activity/problem/assignment encourages the strongest students to take their thinking further.  Ideally, students themselves generate the \next question\" or engage enough in the material to want to pose a further problem.  I recognize that all this sounds almost impossible, but with good grouping I've seen it work.  Much of my experience has been with ELLs--they seem to be especially quick at realizing that they can all learn from each other and that while one student may have the language ability, another may know more math and yet another may be better at spatial skills or art or some other useful ability within group project work etc.  But all students, if encouraged to respect each other and look for learning from each other, can learn to work together with enough work."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I teach adult students and it's not uncommon to hear \I can't do math\" or \"I hate math\".  I used to tease them that I would get an \"I hate math\" jar and have them put a quarter in it every time they said something negative like that.  One day, I thought, hey, why not try some positive reinforcement instead?  I got a jar and wrote \"I love math\" on it and filled it with candy.  I tell students on the first day of every class that if I catch them saying something negative, they will have to stand in front of the class and say the opposite; then they can get a piece of candy.  The students just laugh.  Usually within the first couple of days, I'll catch someone and follow through as promised.  It's all done with a good spirit and I've never had anyone get upset.  The students then start trying to catch each other and having fun with that.  But the amazing thing, is it really has changed how I hear students talk about math and their ability to be successful at it!  I used to hear the negative comments daily and I would always talk to them about the power of words, but now I hardly ever hear students say it anymore.  In fact, I often hear them say \"I love math!\" in a joking tone and I tell them \"fake it till you make it!\"  Once they start seeing success in math, it won't be a joke anymore!"

Before we \think.\"  The judgements come out in gestures, inflections, subtle expressions that we are not even aware of.  It could be the student that we call on, the smile that we give.  If we are to counter these things of which we are not conscious in our interactions with others we must do so consciously and conscientiously.  We have to make a point to compensate._x0007__x0007_For me I find this easier to do with young kids than with adults sometimes.  When it is a parent about my age that I am working with I feel that I more easily slip.  thoughts will pop into my head and I will think, \"where did that come from?\"  Or with  young adults I often do the same.  Quick judgements can be very accurate, but we need to also question them reflectively and ensure that we are not perpetuating negative typing._x0007__x0007_We will never completely get rid of stereotypes.  Our mind sorts automatically to create quick judgements of people.  It is how we have evolved.  However, we know that many of these can be negative (and completely inaccurate), and as educators we need to confront these in ourselves (even if we would like to deny that they exist) and ensure that we treat each student with dignity."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I have quite a diverse teaching background, but to be quite honest, the most fun I have had teaching have occurred while teaching the highest level of math in my district, AP Calculus and the lowest level we offer at the high school, an intervention for those that are 2-3 years behind in math._x0007_My AP Calculus classes are not chosen, they are any student who wants to try it.  I love this way of going about this class because the kids get to hear many different ways of doing a problem, they see the many mistakes each make and realize mistakes are okay, they see that I am patient and willing to work with all of them, which makes them feel good about themselves!  _x0007__x0007_My lowest group, we call it Transitions Math (it is an intervention class, most have not passed Algebra 1 so are 2-3 years behind) come in and tell me on day one that they suck at math, they are not sure why they have a second math class (because they have to be in two to even have a hope of graduating on time), and that no matter what I did they were not going to succeed in either one.  I love challenges!  I usually respond to those opening statements from kids with \Oh really!? Is that a challenge?\"  They laugh but little do they realize I am about to push them further than they have ever wanted to go.  My district adopted a curriculum for this course, but honestly with this group of kids who have never been pushed it was not good.  So I scrapped that and started creating problems and work for them to do which involved creating, building, and sometimes even evaluating each other on work that some admitted seemed harder than what they were doing in their other math class.  They worked on it for me because they told me they wanted to see if they could do it!  HA I had them!  _x0007__x0007_These students had been tracked for too long, teachers saw them as the failures and therefore nothing could be done with them.  Then they run into me who will not give up on them and at first they fight it but then they realize that they have something here they have not been given before!  Students will shine, even the traditionally thought of as lower kids, if you keep your bar up there and allow them various ways to attain that bar.  My belief is never to lower my expectation bar but to give multiple paths for students to attain that level of expectation."

The best thing about this world is that all the creatures are actors playing the part of situations in the real world, and they'll act out any scene you want them to. Tell a variable that she is the length of your swimming pool, and another that he is the size (area) you want your pool to be. Then, if you ask them in the right way, they'll tell you how wide the pool has to be--and you only have to look at a rectangle to figure out how to ask them. I'll show you...

On the other hand, those who quickly found the difference in length between two items were challenged to find the difference between two objects which varied greatly in length._x0007__x0007_In the end, the teacher had the whole class work together in groups to determine the way in which the difference in length between two objects she held in her hands could be determined. This was connected with the position of the numbers on the number line._x0007__x0007_So, the numbers and situations were different and appropriate for different students, but the conversation around the meaning of difference, its relationship to the relative position of numbers on the number line,  and how to determine what the difference is,  was held with everyone._x0007__x0007_In another class, the teacher routinely posted different sets of numbers for problem solving and students chose those which were an appropriate challenge for them._x0007__x0007_The second thing I want to discuss is my opposition to pairing children who are at very different places in their mathematical understanding. Except in cases where the two children have worked out a way so that both profit from the arrangement (and I have seen this happen in classes where repeated conversations around the question \what makes a good mathematics partnership\" and then trying out different partnerships to see how they worked, was an important part of the life of the classroom) neither partner is helped by what often happens - one student does the work and \"explains\" it to the other, who readily agrees that s/he understands._x0007__x0007_The third thing I want to raise is the reality that some children need special support to focus and make sense of mathematics. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: The current focus in our district/school is on explicit direct instruction, for which one stated goal is all students taught grade level standards every day. In practice that often means we spend a lot of time teaching to the middle/low performers. The students who understand concepts are either given independent work or sit through the lesson. Regardless, they get very little of the teacher's time. That's a long way of saying that I do understand the argument that grouping can be a good way to target instruction to a child's readiness. Another model we use at our school involves regrouping students in a grade level for reading instruction. This looks like a classic tracking system. We do our best to be flexible with groups and regroup as often as we can, based on performance, but the reality is once in a group, it is difficult to move up. I've heard and read about many practices for mixed ability grouping. It is frustrating be limited in our ability to use them because they take longer than traditional teaching, in my experience, and at least in the short term. It may be true that that in the long term, you save or come out even on time, but I've found administration is not often willing to experiment with it long enough to reap the benefits. It's not just the administration's fault though. High stakes testing is really behind much of the current state of affairs. I'm eager to delve into the common core standards. They may not be perfect, but they are a step in the right direction.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I've taught at several schools over the course of my career.  Most recently I've been in a school that tracks for math, language arts, and social studies.  When I first came to the school I convinced the math department to reduce the number of tracks but ultimately lost that battle and they went up to five tracks per grade in middle school.  Perhaps trying to mask the lowest group, it's called 'enrichment' rather than 'remediation'.  I had previously taught at a school that had multi-age grouping in which students were grouped by ability for some units (like procedural content) but were mixed 'ability' for others such as geometry.  I use 'ability' in the quotes to emphasize that I really think it was still confusing ability and performance.  That meant that students were re-evaluated at each unit which did result in some mixing and less clear identification of the low v high group.  I understand why the tracking occurs; people think it serves the students because the high achievers can fly without encumbrance and the low achievers can get the attention they need.  It is also hard to teach students at many different levels, especially with classes of 30 - 40 students for 46 minute periods.  On the other hand, it is just an illusion that students who are ability grouped are all at the same level.  It kind of gives the teacher the excuse not to individualize the instruction.  There is also tremendous pressure from parents of higher achieving kids to separate their children from the pack.  I've felt that this grouping does not help students, and I appreciate the specific research you've cited that I can use as evidence to support my own experience.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I am now a volunteer tutor for ESL and find that grouping, even in my situation, can be detrimental to the student. One student has been in the beginning group for a couple of years and he has seen his peers moved on to \higher level\" groups while he has remained at the beginning level group. He tells me he can't learn. But I have found out, by speaking to him in his language, that while he has had only one week of formal schooling (**one week, he repeats**) in his native language, Spanish, he managed to teach himself to read in Spanish. He does not read English because he is confused by seeing vowels which are pronounced so differently in English. He wouldn't even attempt to read a word that is a cognate of a Spanish word, because he thinks it must be pronounced differently (ex. guitar). I am slowly getting him to guess at how English words are read by making him read the consonants the way he would read them in Spanish. He clearly has a disability. I am told he has had a stroke, but while that may slow down his learning, I know it doesn't mean that he can't learn English."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I have taught mixed level math classes for several years, but found that there were always several at the low end who found it difficult to keep up with the rest of the class and several at the top end who \got\" the concepts faster than everyone else.  The faster students were not as much of an issue as the lower level students.  Last year, we identified and grouped students who had learning issues into one class.  On the first day of class, they looked around and knew why they were in that particular class, but were mostly happy not to be in the \"regular\" sections.  We also added a support teacher and modified the lessons slightly, although the students still wrote all the same assessments as the other students.  At the end of the year, many of these students were as or more successful than they had been in previous math courses.  Even though they were separated into a different class, they felt that they were given extra support so they were willing to work hard to achieve success.  In this case, grouping these students was the \"right\" thing to do.  It also helped even out the other sections so that teachers were able to address more issues with specific students as they were more homogeneous in their abilities.  I think that it worked for us because we had very specific documentation and previous assessments on our students so were very careful in choosing who were best suited for the grouped class.  I know that it wouldn't work for every school, but it did work for us."

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I grew up in a country where there were no tracking in education. So, I have no experience what it feels like to be in either track. However, teaching here in the United States gave me some experience on how kids feel in this system, mainly those who are placed in grade level grouping. They loose confidence in their ability and they think they are not smart and that those who are in advanced classes are the smart ones. It is self-fulfilling prophecy, even if they are the brightest, unfortunately, they believe they aren't and they become what they believe. There is a wide academic gap between the two groups at the 7th or 8th grade levels, as I see it in my school. All students get promoted to the next level regardless whether they learned the maths or not, as a result the academic gap gets wider and wider as students move on from k1 to 8th grade. _x0007_Doing this course was a great advantage to me. The more I read about the research findings the more I become convinced with mixed ability groupings. At the same time, I wonder, do we phase it out? or do we just do it all at once?

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: One thing I've read about is that Support classes find unusual success when they pre-teach the material, rather than re-teach the material already covered. _x0007__x0007_Think about it this way, when you use Support primarily to re-teach, you're admitting to the students that they're slower, that they're not as smart. Many of them are willing to take the Support Class because they want the extra assistance, but it is a subtle acknowledgement that they aren't \smart.\" _x0007__x0007_When you pre-teach the material, you're decreasing the cognitive load that the students will go through on the day of class. Instead of \"Factoring?!? What does that word mean?\", they've practiced the word in resource class, and perhaps did some 4th-grade multiplication/factorization review and started the basics. Now, when they're in a group with high and low kids, the kids from the Support class have background knowledge to contribute. They're smart! They also will be able to follow along better with the lectured that's designed for-the-middle, because the very basics were covered the day before in Support class. And, the kids who traditionally get rewarded for having the background knowledge (the hand-raising volunteer types) have to step up their game because they suddenly have a lot more competition for teacher's pet. _x0007__x0007_I don't remember what study it was that showed this effect, but it's definitely something to look into. It makes much better use of time than having a kid sit lost and confused through the difficult material, and then handing them easier work the next day in Support class. It sends mixed messages as to what rigor level is expected, and it can mean that the main math class was a waste because the kid didn't feel comfortable with the word Factorization and thus 90 minutes of material went over his head. I also have seen the Support classes can turn into hand-holding classes where the steps are more and more broken down by the teacher who is \"assisting\" the student, whereas when the material is being pre-taught, the goal of the Support class is about growing your background knowledge on a topic up to a comfortable level, and it's becomes a safe place for asking questions you don't know, which will be helpful when you learn them \"for real\" tomorrow. _x0007__x0007_Anyway, best of luck - hope this helped!"

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Our school first assigns students in classes with SPED and gifted together (because they get extra support/time away from the homeroom) and then fill in slots to form their version of heterogeneous classes of about 32 students.  Our administrators do not believe in retaining students so at the fourth grade level you receive students that read first grade thru seventh grade level.  So we have such a broad range with some students that can't read/comprehend questions while others breeze through everything.  We are made to teach in timed blocks...1 1/2 hr. reading, 1 hr. math, 40 mins. for SS, 40 mins. for Science, and 30 mins. for writing.  We receive negative comments on evals if we go over 5 mins. We have an assistant occasionally (1/2 rdg, 1/2 hr math).  Teaching to the middle would leave the majority of the class lost or bored.  Trying to do guided math with 6 at a time is impossible with so many students and the limited time.  The past 2 years, the school's solution was to rotate and create homogeneous groups for math so that teaching to the middle would be more effective and as much intervention/guided math as possible would compliment.  My philosophy differs....Maybe we should not focus on grades (promote/retain) as much as on skill/concept achievement or have transitional classes.  The 'first grade level' students often become frustrated and become behavior problems because they need so many learning experiences and there is not adequate time due to pacing and benchmark testing.   I think we need more instructional support/smaller class sizes and they should be heterogeneous.  The jump that doubles the class size and 75% of the students did not master third grade is tough!   Ideas????
