Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I find that ability grouping does not work for me.  My class size will be over 30 this year (fourth grade), and was about 25 last year (3rd grade).  When I did experiment with ability grouping, I was frustrated with my teaching for several reasons.  First, even within the \groupings\" that I made, students had different needs and strengths.  My differentiated lessons didn't seem to work, and I felt that many students were not challenged._x0007_   This year, I will be experimenting with mixed-group lessons where students work together to find solutions.  Our school is adapting the Contexts for Learning math curriculum, and I am excited to see what students will do with these lessons.  I'm a bit concerned with the mixed-grouping because when I did do these type of lessons last year (I experimented a lot to see what would work), I sometimes found that students who felt they could not do the math simply paired up with a partner they felt was strong in math and did not learn much at all.  I have a lot of prepping to do to place students together to optimize the growth mindset.  _x0007_   I think sometimes teachers feel that ability grouping is an easier way to teach, and that may seem to be since mixed-group teaching really requires a lot of thinking and preparing to orchestrate a lesson where all students are challenged to think and understand.  But I really feel that these mixed group lessons provide the best learning environment for all.  If anyone has any suggestions on classroom tips to engage all students to participate in mixed-group lessons, I'd be interested in reading them!"

But math requires actual effort. If at first you do not succeed, you must try again, rewrite the problem, learn to sleep on it, learn to push yourself to do what you do not find easy. It is good for you but you must 'develop a taste for it.'_x0007__x0007_Naturally, many adults  including parents and even educators persist in propagating a set of negative messages. Add to that the low esteem in which memorization is held and you have an activity based exposure to math concepts, many math concepts and insufficient practice so that no mastery results. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I have so many questions about this topic. As an 8th grade math teacher, I teach two regular classes and one \honors\" class of math.  I teach the same curriculum to all of the students but with the honors class, I can move more quickly or delve into topics a bit more deeply.  I have to slow down quite a bit in the other classes and review work such as how to work with fractions or how to find percent of a number.  These topics are not part of the 8th grade curriculum but many of the kids need a refresher on these topics as we explore functions.  In the honors class, most of the kids already have a solid foundations in these areas so this gives us a chance to explore something else.  We put as many kids as possible (32) into the honors class and definitely try to push kids into the honors group if they are borderline.  We use test scores and teacher recommendation to make the decision.  We are also careful that the demographics are representative of our population.  We  make sure to have the same high expectations for all of the classes.  Many of the students in my two regular classes end up improving their scores significantly by the end of 8th grade.  Some test out of algebra and end up taking geometry as 9th graders.  I treat all of my students the same, whether they are in the honors class or not.  In fact, they don't really even realize if they are in the honors class or not because we don't make a big deal out of it.  I am not a believer in tracking students--I believe that ability grouping should be fluid and that expectations should be high for all students.  I look at where students are at in the beginning of 8th grade and create my classes, and this does include an honors group.  _x0007__x0007_So, my main questions would be:_x0007_1.  Are Gifted and Talented education, Response to Instruction and Special Education considered to be tracking/ability grouping?  Does research show that these are ineffective?_x0007_2. Is there a time when ability grouping makes sense based on widely varying abilities such as this?_x0007_3.  Is there a certain age when ability grouping does make sense? Perhaps it makes sense for 14 year olds but not 5 year olds?_x0007_4. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I don't work in a classroom - I tutor homeschooled and special needs students who need a different way of teaching for each one.  I can imagine it is hard to try to accommodate everyone's needs but I do think it can be done.  When my sons were in lower elementary school, their classes had stations or centers for both math and language arts.  I helped in the classroom and saw how the center offered a chance for each student to work at their own level on same or similar tasks.  In response to a prompt that often was built around the monthly theme of homes or gardens or the circus, etc., one student might have been using base 10 blocks to model a problem with adding tens and ones, while another used pencil and paper to add and carry 3-4 places, or another drew images showing addition, and so on. A parent helper or aide would be there to offer support and inspiration. Or sometimes it was set up so that one station had similar but more complicated tasks, the next had easier concepts or tasks, and the third, a simpler task yet, and the student could choose the task that was at their level.  This worked well and instead of grades, the school used a rubric for evaluation.  But I also recently watched my husband try the function task Jo gave us with the block towers and I thought he wouldn't be able to figure it out (I had found 4 different ways to look at the function) but he surprised me with a very different way of looking at the problem and I could see that his math esteem had grown when I told him that! I wish he had had a teacher who could have worked with him in his best way of learning or that he could have worked in a center-based math class with manipulatives.  Anyway, I like the idea of the growth mindset classroom, as it allows many more children the opportunity to be part of the learning community with their classmates and offers collaboration and problem-solving practice for higher level thinking and tasks.

The goal of beginning the year with this is to let the students know that I am not always going to be the one with the answer and that they will be expected to be involved, try things, try more things and convince themselves that they are right._x0007__x0007_The activity:  Give students the a package of assorted balloons with a price tag._x0007_Instructions:  Your task is to determine the fewest # of these packages of balloons that we would need to buy to fill the classroom with balloons.  You can ask me up to 3 questions and no more.  Choose your questions carefully as you really only have 3 questions.  Don't waste them on things you can figure out._x0007__x0007_This activity gets at so many great things including persistence and not being afraid to just try some things.  I also video tape them working so that the next day we can reflect and analyze their current work patterns and what they think needs to change.  This also provides me an opportunity to let them know what I expect of them in terms of taking risks and making mistakes.

I then add that I've taught math longer than he has, and I add that I don't have the problem here -- he does. I make sure to always give students the choice to grow or quit. Kids want power struggles, and I tell them when they are ready, I will be there._x0007__x0007_My rules are simple:_x0007_1. A student must always come up with an answer first, and they must memorize the gist of the problem. I pick up their paper and have them prove this. I tell them I expect mistakes and frustration and for them to feel dumb and unsure; if I didn't want this, I'd assign these middle schoolers connect the dots and 1+1 problems. Of course, no one would learn anything._x0007_2. The work must be in writing. Then I make students defend what they've done. Why? Many students flat out lie. Very brazen, but so many people artificially inflate students' self-esteem that they don't know how to deal with disappointment (I have a growth mindset, but yes, I'm disappointed in failure; I bet Edison was disappointed 8,999 times until he got the light bulb correct, and imagine how different it would be today if he had stumbled on the correct method the first time!)._x0007_3. The student must do what I ask. Many students call me over, have many conceptual and procedural errors, and then they berate my methods and tell me what to do. Hey, we all want to be correct, but when you need help, you need help. I tell students upfront that if they want to do everything their way, leave me out of it -- I will summon you when I need help.

We don't need to grind up children in learning factories called schools._x0007__x0007_The only way to really support true learning, and not just be coming up with more Skinner box reward systems to successfully get the children through this factory, is to make school optional.  If you get rid of the compulsory nature of school, it will transform itself into an institution that we can actually be proud of, like public libraries.  Imagine if you were force marched and sat down in a public library every day, and then told exactly what book you were supposed to read and have memorized and you will have a test on it tomorrow?  Would you still want to go to the library??  The beauty of the library is that is is a free resource, but no one is forced to use it.  You use it when you want to for your own purposes._x0007__x0007_To pretend that committees can decide for you what you need to know and what you need to learn at every moment of your day, plan away your days in 10 minute intervals, because crowd control is going to get pretty sticky really fast if you run out of things to do... Now you're seeing school as I see it.  And so \untracking\" is such a small tip of the iceberg.  Most of the terrible messages our children are receiving about life and education are coming from school and school systems.  Let's dismantle tracking.  Let's dismantle assessment.  Let's dismantle the idea of a core curriculum.  Those things are touted for \"safety\", but there's nothing safe in handing over your children to an institution and expecting that monstrosity to raise them.  Let the children choose what they want to learn and be actually eager to learn._x0007__x0007_By all means, mix up the people taking different subjects.  Who says you can't be learning Statistics at age 7?  Or when you're 39?  It is a broad enough topic to have interesting information for people at any age.  When you mix up groups, the strong will help the weak in a learning environment.  It is normal to start at the bottom and work to the top.  You can do it at your own pace.  You can drop out and decide that you would rather learn about something else.  That is why people love games.  No one forces them to play, and people who have played the game longer will help you learn it.  You always start out a noob, and you just learn on"

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Four years ago, my first year teaching, I was warned about a \difficult\" student before the start of the school year. I was told to put his mother's phone number on my cell so I could call her immediately when he gave me trouble. No one had anything positive to say about him. I was troubled by the universally negative view of this child and was determined to give him a positive experience in a classroom. During the first week I called his mom. She picked up the phone and said, \"What has he done now?\" I told her how nice it was to have him in my class (I had made sure to make the call during the \"honeymoon\" period) and I gave specific examples of things he had done successfully in class and mentioned that I saw that he clearly had the potential to do well. I heard a huge sigh of relief. We talked about working together to make this year a good stepping off point for high school and that I wanted to try to channel his energy into being a leader. Throughout the year, I continued to reinforce my belief in his potential by identifying examples of clear mathematical thinking even when he might have made arithmetic errors. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I did teach at the local Jr college here in Nevada.  I have seen a lot of the \lower-level\" individuals, whether just coming from high school all the way to those that are just improving their skills in my math classes.  I taught Basic Math, Pre-Algebra and Intro to Algebra.  I spend about 45 minutes talking with the students, the first night of class, about what is it about math that they don't like/get.  I found out that it was all about the teacher.  If the teacher didn't encourage them to want to learn, try again when a mistake was made let alone explain why their answer was incorrect, the student just stop wanting/liking math.  In 2012, I had a student that I had for Pre-Algebra (7:20pm class) send me an email.  I sat at my desk and just cried because she thanked me for helping her understand math.  I had the students build a set of basic resources that they could use in any math class.  There is/was tracking at this particular school and she earned an A from me which meant that she could either take a 2-semester Algebra class or a 1 semester class.  She chose to take the 1 semester class.  She told me that she struggled to learn the material, made mistakes, learned from them and persisted through the class.  She told me that she earned an A in that class.  I was so happy to here this.  In my class you just didn't sit in class.  The students worked in groups, did work in class, got up and went to the board to show what they knew.  In doing these things, the students felt comfortable about making mistakes, asking for help (from their classmates rather than me).  _x0007__x0007_My suggestion to you would be:_x0007_1. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I think I have a moral responsibility to address issues of inequity in math education. As a leader of a statewide organization devoted to supporting improvements (new norms) in the quality of teaching and learning in math classrooms, it would be foolish to think that we can actually make real progress doing that without uncovering and addressing some of these deeply seeded issues. _x0007__x0007_There are a number of mechanisms through which we can engage our stakeholders in these conversations. This fall, we are going to launch our New Normal secondary PD project with a talk that Jo has agreed to do around Growth Mindset. This talk will help to surface some of the underlying issues around equity, bias, and systemic issues that actually contribute to problems such as stereotyping. I also plan to use articles such as the de-tracking article Jo wrote to probe deeper into the underlying reasons why we as adults actually perpetuate these problems. No question people's beliefs are a part of what we must work on as a community. I think getting our principals on board is important. Some of our high school principals for example are taking courageous steps to make changes (e.g. honors option in heterogeneously grouped classes). Others continue to suggest they will lose kids if they de-track. I think structures like tracking actually inhibit our ability to erase these stereotypes and inequities so, I know in my work, these more deeply seeded issues are the ones our community is poised to address in the coming year and beyond.

So, when I saw this problem, I immediately took 29/4 and got 7 remainder 1, which means 700 with 1 quarter left over...725.  This process has similarities to i^29  = i and other situations where certain groupings reproduce patterns.  Another example is \what is the last digit of 9^1000?\"  This problem produces an overflow error on most calculating devices, but we can solve by looking for a pattern within the last digit and then dividing the 1000 by the number of numbers in our pattern and applying the remainder.  _x0007_So, what I'm trying to say here is that I thought that putting Vivian's method in the category of the distributive property was nice, but the distributive property may not have been what she was really thinking.  She may have simply been grouping 4 quarters to make dollars. If we happened to be in the context of counting quarters, I would suggest that this is what we would have done...make stacks of 4 quarters until we used our quarters up then count the hundreds and than count the leftovers by 25 cents apiece."

Math faculty are typically folks who are good at math and may have difficulty working with students who don't immediately grasp these concepts. These faculty often teach math in the same way they learned it, which is a very rule/algorithm-based method, rather than experientially or contextually. However, the reason these students are in remedial math is because they didn't learn from these methods in the first place (in middle school and high school) so teaching this way in college is not going to help them any more so._x0007__x0007_However, I think another reason that isn't mentioned here has to do with non-cognitive and affective factors. Many students have an anxiety and fear about math, and come in to a math course believing it is difficult, which makes it harder to reach them and get them interested in math. I think this is a common attitude in American culture that \math is hard\" and therefore it is something to be feared and something that it's okay to be bad at. For students who didn't have positive experiences with math at a young age, teachers are fighting against this kind of negative affect."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: When talking about mistakes being helpful for brain growth, there was little attention on what happens in the case of recalling information (and providing a correct answer) without making a mistake. It was almost implicit that what happened was \no growth\"._x0007__x0007_I have a theory based on what I learned about neural networks. When training a  neural network, there are 2 activities, creating new connections and reinforcing \"good\" existing connections. This reinforcement was critical for producing a well trained network and it was what made occasional \"bad\" connections unimportant. Recall activity, if not conducive to growth, it may play a key role in this reinforcement portion and still be extremely important._x0007__x0007_Neural network learning curves are often modeled using a sigmoid function (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sigmoid_function), this describes the fact that initial learning is shallow, but after some reinforcement it gets to a point where the learning becomes much stronger very quickly (where the slope of the sigmoid becomes much steeper) and then it reaches saturation, where it takes a lot more effort to produce an improvement. _x0007__x0007_The key may be in finding the right balance between growth and reinforcement. If we focus too much on reinforcement (which may be a problem in the current education systems) then we reach saturation point and simply get diminishing returns. When we're close to saturation, focusing on growth is likely to produce much better results, but I believe there is also risk if focusing too much on the growth mindset and not providing sufficient reinforcement._x0007__x0007_Of <nameRedac_<anon_screen_name_redacted>> this is very speculative, and based on extrapolation from research done for other purposes that may or may not apply here. It should be confirmed more scientifically, but I would like to hear comments and opinions from others about this."

When students make the first type of mistake, they can learn how to correct their conceptual or procedural bearings, or correct the simple mis-calculation.  But, when the student has no idea conceptually of what the problem entails, they will have greater difficulty learning from the mistake if the concept, procedure, or calculation does not become clear in the process of revising._x0007_How does this make all of us feel?_x0007_When I was taking classes in higher math in the old days, I learned the procedure from the professor and knew how to identify a procedure with an exercise or a problemand there is a difference between the two.  I always taught myself to think: What did I learn that is disguised in this problem I am not currently seeing?  Once I asked myself that important question, I saw right away what needed to be done, and proceeded to work the exercise or solve the problem.  I was successful in math until the way math is taught changed.  _x0007_In 1996, I took a prob and stats class where I worked out exercises in the above fashion, and earned an A in the class.  Did I really understand the usefulness of prob and stats?  A little bit because, after all, we did do some applied word problems._x0007_Fast forward to 2011.  I was taking a graduate level course in Teaching Algebra and the professor gave us real life problems in probability and statistics; and the numbers were ugly.  He did not take much time to refresh our memoriesin my case 15 yearson the mechanics of prob and stats, but did assign some background reading.  We were then assigned extremely difficult problems for homework, and I struggled with them.  It was if I had no compass at all.  But, this is how we are expected to learn mathematics: by doing it and struggling with it.  This, however, was a different kind of struggle for me.  Fifteen years later and working under the new approach, I could not correct my errors in the graduate level prob/stats class.  _x0007_He was a mathematics professor in a Masters program designed for mathematics teachers, which means he was a mathematician teaching mathematics to math educators, not all of whom were ma

You are a data scientist who labels text indicating whether the message is a answer or not with the label options [0.0, 1.0], where 1 indicates the message is a answer and 0 indicates it is not. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: In working with students on such problems I abandon the goal of representing the situation in one variable and let them use A, B, and C to start with. I don't see a need to use just one variable, and having 3 variables allows the students to keep the original problem in their head a little longer in working the problem. Jumping right to using 'x' to show the relationship between the three piles is too big a step.  So:  B = A + 2; C = 4A; A + B + C = 14.  Then I talk about the importance of the equals sign.  The equals sign is a like a balance scale.  The equals sign means you have the same amount of stuff on the left that you do on the right.  The equals sign means that the thing on the left (same amount of stuff as the right) can be substituted for the thing on the right anywhere it appears in this problem.  And vise versa -- the thing on the right can be substituted for the thing on the left anywhere it appears in the problem.  So in this case, you can substitute A + 2 for B anywhere it appears in this situation, and 4A for C anywhere it appears in this situation.  So A + B + C = 14 can become A + (A + 2) + (4A) = 14.  I will actually write out A + B + C = 14 with lots of space, and then erase the B and write \(A + 2)\" in its place; erase C and write \"(4A)\" in its place.  At this point I will point out we now have a mathematical representation of the problem of piles of rocks and how many is in each pile.  We check that this mathematical representation truly does represent the problem.  Then I ask them for a leap of faith -- to not think about the original problem, but just look at the equation.  Now there is one variable in the equation and let's find out what it is -- view it as a puzzle.  I let them do any manipulation they want to as long as that manipulation honors the equals sign.  We look at the result of each manipulation, asking does it make the equation look less complex -- always keeping in mind that at this point, the goal is to get to \"A = ...\" -- finding out what A is.  Once we have A, I have the student look back at the original problem and tell me what we've found out.  I ask have we answered the question originally asked?  If a single variable, such as x is used, it is easy to think the problem is solved once we find x.  But by using A, and looking back at the original problem, we find that we know A, but there is still more work to do to find B and C."

I always start the year by asking the students what they want to learn this year, as well as what they think theyre going to learn. After we talk about that a bit, I ask them if they think its going to be easy or hard. Our conversation always finishes with my promise to them: that we will work on some easy things (because some of them already know something about those things) and some hard things (because there are some things they havent tried before), but I will never ask them to do anything they cant handle. I tell them I know they will be able to do anything I ask of them. Then I remind them of this throughout the year if they ever say something is too hard. This year, I will add to this a discussion about the brain, probably starting by asking what they know about the brain and eventually telling them some of the neat things Ive learned about it and how we can actually make ourselves smarter by trying different things, making mistakes, then trying them again till we get them right. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I have found that in many classes and trainings they frown on having students memorize their times tables. I always insist on this as a daily warm up.  It sure helps students to reduce fractions, know which number easily factors out, etc. I have seen a huge confidence building by focusing on quickly retrieving facts and carry this over to less guess and check in division and lots of other. This concept of if students understand basic multiplication facts, they didn't need to memorize them. In fact my thesis was on this topic, much to the amaze and disagreement of my instructor. I have had a huge success with students starting to enjoy math more, despite being told for 25 years this is not a good practice.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I think the most important idea to gain from number talks is that there are many ways of solving number problems and not just methods, but perspectives.  One person looks at numbers or numbers of things differently and I'm not sure you would be aware of it unless people shared those perspectives. So you can see that math can be creative and use personal perspective, which I never really thought about for.  I was really struck how showing the various ways to solve 18 x 5 illustrates the distributive property, instead of the oft used letters a(b+c)=ab+ac.  Students memorize that and don't get the point of doing it or how it can be useful.  Number talk shows the distributive property as actually useful (It answers the question--When am I ever going to use this?)

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: While all 4 choices are appropriate reasons, I think both teaching methods and student's lack of functional knowledge impact the other 2. There is a real disconnect from what research says about how math should be taught and how school systems interpret that information. In my state, the political powers that be are more interested in increasing the \rigor\" versus teaching what's developmentally appropriate for each student at his/her specific grade and age level. We are all about \"spirally\" with the expected outcome being mastery of each skill.  What ends up happening is that we keep throwing concepts and processes at students as they progress through the grade levels without giving them the needed and necessary time (one size fits all pacing guides) to obtain a true understanding of what's being taught. As teachers we are asked to take courses about number and number sense, but aren't given the time to implement what we've learned. My state is one of the few states in the U.S. that hasn't subscribed to the Common Core standards which seem to be more developmentally appropriate for students. When was the last time that teachers were given the opportunity to choose how and what they teach (and I'm not talking about textbook adoption), but rather given the directive from above?"

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Reading through some of these responses caused me to contemplate what I saw as the 'gap' between parents and children - by this I mean, what happened to create the type of parent that essentially fears maths and is then forced to feel this fear again when talking to the teachers of their children or when faced with being asked for help with maths homework by their offspring._x0007__x0007_I then thought about my Y11 class from last year.  This was a class of 'foundation' students.  Students whose highest expected level of achievement at GCSE would be a grade C.  Half of these students were expected to fail to achieve grade C (and did).  Most of these students wanted to achieve this magical grade C because it would open doors for them in the world of college and careers._x0007__x0007_All of these students had experienced repeated failure in maths mostly throughout their time in school.  Some were willing to work hard to achieve their grade (and did).  _x0007__x0007_The key thing I recall though is that NONE of these students enjoyed maths.  The carrot at the end of the stick that helped them maintain their efforts in class (and at home in prep for their exam) was that once they had bagged their grade C they would never have to do maths again!  As teachers we even used this carrot with flagging students \Come on, you might as well do the work now otherwise you will end up doing maths again in college!\"_x0007__x0007_It won't be too many years before these students turn into the kinds of parents we are talking about.  As  I see it today, the whole purpose of maths education in English schools is to achieve at least a grade C at GCSE.  The whole purpose of maths GCSE grades is to divide society.  Why then should students who can see that they have struggled or failed to make the grade be positive about maths when bringing up their own children?  Without intervention the best we can hope for is that these students will go on to encourage their children to work hard at something that is not enjoyable in order to achieve a good grade."

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I see the same experiences at my school. Some students are tracked early into Algebra I and Geometry so there are various levels of those. Algebra I has the most tracking (some start in 7th, some in 8th in parts, some in one semester in 9th, some in two semesters in 9th, and some in three semesters in 9th/10th). This class is the most failed class in 9th grade and has the worst of all our math classes on the end-of-course state exam scores despite (or maybe in spite of) how much the school has tried to \individualize\" the pace of it. I think it's exactly what you're saying though that because these kids are in what they know is a slow-paced class with other slow-paced kids they're not excited about it and there is no one there (students or teachers) to challenge them and encourage them to work at higher levels. [As a similar side note, Geometry was the next most \"tracked\" class with the options of Geometry or Honors Geometry in one semester or Geometry in 2 semesters (which was really only weeding out the top 10% and the bottom 5% from the regular classes). Geometry scores are the next lowest math scores in the building.]_x0007__x0007_On the flip side, Algebra II (which I teach currently) has no tracking aside from the fact that it is not necessarily \"required\" for every student. Most students will take it and there are no levels of tracking to it so the very bright 9th graders are mixed in with the average 10th and 11th graders and the 12th graders who haven't seen math in over a year). It seems like a challenge but I love it because of the variety. I give challenging questions to all of them and am pleasantly surprised to see how many try the challenges no matter what level of skill they feel they have. The discussions are more interesting and useful with the variety of skills in the room and the test scores at the end of the year are the best in the department too. So I'm with you in thinking that tracking has a significant impact on the \"enjoyment\" and successfulness of the class for all students."

First, there is an opportunity to see how different students in the class see the same arrangement differently, which can challenge everyone to try to see it the way another saw it. It is also an opportunity to stretch the students to develop a mental image and hold that in their head rather than counting by ones. If they can see 4 as a square, then they can hold that in their minds and not have to count it, and when they see it again in another arrangement they can use it without counting. Most of all, our practices and attitudes fall into the grip of the fixed mindset.  I certainly agree that testing also leads to significant misplacement of students.  Many are in the wrong groups!  Even if grouping worked best, many students are not appropriately placed and find it next to impossible to rise._x0007__x0007_Just the other day, a student was wild with happiness after school.  I asked him why. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I work at a public charter high school where students come in from 40 different middle schools (or home school settings).  We have un-tracked heterogenous classes except for about 20 students a year who are put ahead one grade level in their classes.  This means I have classes of 32 students whose ACT math scores are 20 points apart.  It's definitely been a challenge to find ways to allow all of my students to grow and feel challenged, but at a level where they also feel successful.  I find that I try to attack old topics with a different spin or from a different point of view to level the playing field a little.  I've created extension work for the students who finish early to keep them challenged. I also do a lot of groupwork from a complex instruction framework. All things considered, my system is working better than some others in the school.  However, I find that students still have very fixed mindsets and act as if they're tracked into ability groups no matter what.  It creates a lot of status issues that contribute to fixed mindset thinking. _x0007__x0007_So my question is how can I start to undo the tracking and messages that have happened before me and my school?  These messages and experiences have seemed to make kids believe in their track, even if it disappears for some at my school.

Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: I was always a conscientious, high achieving student in all academic areas except for math. When I was a sophomore taking Geometry, I struggled a great deal. I tried and tried and my teacher one day said to me, \I know how hard you are trying and you aren't really getting it. I think you should drop Geometry and take typing.\" Sadly, I did follow her directions and to this day, I regret it. I currently am in a literacy coach capacity but work with students in grades K-5 for different academic areas. I do not want any student to ever get a response from a teacher like I got. I often wondered years later, \"Why didn't she tutor me after school or suggest that my parents get a tutor for me?\" I assumed she thought I would never \"get\" it, so what was the point? When I have taught math to students in second and third grade, I always wanted students to be able to explain their thinking and how they arrived at the answer they did even if it was incorrect. I think having students work in groups together is a powerful learning experience so each can share their thoughts. I also believe the teacher must be circulating through the classroom and listening to what students are saying. I also remembered that when I was in school, we \"had\" to memorize our times tables. To this day, I know them. Students today have difficulty memorizing them. For me, it was a drill and kill type learning. I have had students who have learned their times tables using songs and music. Others who write and write the times tables repeatedly do not have success memorizing. So I believe there is not one right way for each student to learn and we as teachers need to find the different avenues available for students and offer them different paths to achieve goals."

I didn't see much trouble with the new arrangement ... until my oldest child started into my classes. She, as a hard-working and inquisitive student, suffered terribly because she was constantly waiting for other students to catch up. The classic line I remember from 8th grade Math was (in December) \Papa, I learned something NEW today in class!\"  We changed to ability grouping shortly after my colleague's son suffered the same fate in an Algebra class.  _x0007__x0007_Honestly, since behavior and effort affected the decision as much as ability, we changed it because we were tired of watching hard-working kids get held back by clowns.  I don't require cross country runners to train at the same pace for the same distances, and I don't feel good about doing the equivalent with my math students.  I do spend a lot of time encouraging both groups (remember that even within the groups there is a wide variety of performance because there are only two classes) to think and communicate carefully, to try new methods of solution, and to not limit themselves with their attitude about their ability ... be it positive or negative._x0007__x0007_We(my colleague and I) both recognize that we have growth opportunities when it comes to differentiating instruction for different ability levels within the same classroom. Respond with only one of the options shown and label the following text: Throughout my schooling career I have often times been asked why do you want to be a teacher? I reply with the same answer each time which is that I want to make a difference in students lives. Educators have a tremendous impact on their students lives, and I cannot think of something more rewarding than knowing I impacted a childs life forever._x0007_ All students learn differently, therefore, answering the question, how do students learn? with one simple answer is close to impossible. A more accurate question is what teaching styles, techniques, or strategies are used in your classroom to promote high quality learning? Individuals learn at different speeds and are often times at various academic levels. With that said, we, as educators and student role models must seek out learning styles that click best with our students and their personalities. Once a teacher and student seek learning styles, techniques, and strategies that promotes positive, enjoyable learning is when I believe a student will learn at his/her best._x0007_In my future teaching career, I will discover such teaching styles that will enhance my students academic performances by planning several lessons that incorporate Howard Gardners multiple intelligences. For instance, I may give my students the option to work on a classroom assignment by themselves or with a partner, demonstrating Interpersonal/Intrapersonal intelligence.
